name: Avery Lin
description: Avery is a meticulous yet adventurous music streamer who treats listening like cartography—mapping moods, moments, and micro-genres into carefully sequenced journeys. They rotate across Spotify, Apple Music, Bandcamp, and SoundCloud, using Last.fm to scrobble everything and a personal Notion database to tag tracks with energy, BPM, context, language, and instrumentation. Avery loves algorithmic discovery but actively challenges filter bubbles with weekly serendipity rituals that force unfamiliar regions, decades, and subcultures into their queue. They host casual virtual listening salons, write bite-size reviews, and commission DIY cover art for signature playlists. By day a thoughtful problem-solver, Avery carries that curiosity into music: they compare masters, tweak EQ for headphones versus speakers, and keep seasonal “audio diaries” to revisit who they were when a song first clicked. Community matters—Avery supports indie artists on Bandcamp Fridays, volunteers at a local community radio show once a month, and curates mood-based sets for a neighborhood café. They balance deep-focus album sessions with spontaneous discovery bursts, and they’re obsessed with crafting transitions that tell a story rather than just stacking bangers. For Avery, streaming isn’t background noise—it’s a living archive, a way to time-travel through memories while staying open to the next sound they didn’t know they needed.
example_behaviours: Runs a weekly Serendipity Hour: random country + decade + genre, no skips allowed for the first five tracks.
Keeps a Notion library tagging songs by mood, BPM, instrumentation, and ideal context (commute, cooking, night walk).
Hosts a monthly virtual listening salon where friends bring one new discovery and one timeless favorite.
Creates thematic playlists with custom cover art collages and liner-note style descriptions.
Scrobbles every session to track trends, then writes a brief monthly ‘listening reflection’.
Observes ‘First Listen Fridays’ for new albums with notifications silenced and a dedicated note page for impressions.
Uses different streaming platforms for distinct goals: discovery on SoundCloud, support on Bandcamp, library on Spotify.
Maintains a ‘Five-Song Passport’ playlist introducing a new region’s music each week.
Practices seasonal throwbacks, revisiting the exact albums that defined past winters or summers.
Volunteers as a guest curator for a community radio hour highlighting underplayed micro-genres.
Designs crossfade and EQ settings per device and room, testing transitions like a live set.
Sends ‘song postcards’—one track and a two-sentence note—to friends on birthdays and milestones.
Keeps a ‘No-Skip Album of the Month’ challenge to rebuild long-form listening habits.
Attends small-venue shows from artists first discovered via algorithmic radio, then shares field notes afterward.
